title: What I Wish Doctors Knew: STI Testing and Black Women’s Health

content: I’ve had more speculums in my body than lovers. More blood drawn by gloved hands than hands that held me. That’s the cost of living with chronic illness and being a Black woman who insists on staying alive.

Since I was 21, I’ve had a full STI panel every three months — right alongside my A1c. It’s been over two decades of routine labs, pelvic exams, urine samples, and nasal-voiced nurses asking when my last period was, like they’re asking for my astrological sign.
But even with all that experience, even with the language and discipline and courage to advocate for myself, I’ve left more than a few appointments in tears.
Because what I know in my body doesn’t always match what doctors are trained to believe about it.
I Wish Doctors Knew I'm Not an Anomaly

Yes, I get tested quarterly. Yes, I ask for the full panel, not just HIV and gonorrhea. Yes, I know what PrEP is. Yes, I’ve had partners I asked to test with me. That doesn’t make me superhuman. It doesn’t make me suspicious.

Yes, I get tested quarterly. Yes, I ask for the full panel, not just HIV and gonorrhea. Yes, I know what PrEP is. Yes, I’ve had partners I asked to test with me. That doesn’t make me superhuman. It doesn’t make me suspicious.

content: It makes me normal — or at least, it should.

But too many doctors look at me with raised eyebrows when I ask for what I need. They double-check my age. They ask if I really need to test again. They suggest, in tone or in body language, that I’m either doing too much or been doing too much .
As if informed Black women are too rare to be real.
What I wish they’d understand is this: We are out here. We are informed. We are proactive. We are paying attention. We just aren’t always believed.
I Wish They Knew That "Comprehensive Care" Isn’t Just Clinical
STI testing isn’t just about swabs and vials. It’s about safety. Psychological safety. Emotional safety. Cultural safety.
I’ve had providers who wouldn’t say the word “vagina.” Ones who assumed I was heterosexual. Ones who made my HIV diagnosis the main character of my chart — every question routed through that lens.

content: But I’ve also had doctors who called me beloved . Ones who explained each test before they did it. Who never made assumptions. Who didn’t flinch when I said, “I’m positive.” Who treated me like I wasn’t broken, but informed.
There’s a difference between doing your job and honoring your patient. And Black women can feel the difference.
We’ve learned to read tone like vital signs. We’ve learned to ask for the nurse who looks like us. We’ve learned to translate our pain into something measurable so it gets taken seriously.
We’ve learned, in short, to work around the system that was never built with us in mind.
I Wish They Knew That Judgment Is Deadlier Than the Diagnosis

Black women are more likely to contract STIs. That’s a fact. Not because we’re reckless but because we are structurally neglected. Less likely to be tested. Less likely to be taken seriously. More likely to experience provider bias, economic barriers, and misinformation.

content: But what I’ve learned is this: Stigma is the real pre-existing condition. It’s the reason some women don’t get tested. The reason some don’t come back. The reason people sit with symptoms for months because they’re afraid of what a diagnosis might mean — not medically, but socially .
When I was diagnosed with HIV, I didn’t cry because of the virus. I cried because I knew what people would say.
I wish providers understood that. That when a patient walks in asking for an STI panel, she’s not just asking for care — she’s asking not to be punished for seeking it.
What I Know Now

I know that my body is not up for debate. I know that asking for what I need doesn’t make me difficult — it makes me informed. I know that I’m not alone, even if the waiting room makes it feel that way. And I know that every time I advocate for myself, I make space for another Black woman to do the same.

sections.heading: What I Wish They’d Say Instead
content: “I’m glad you’re here.” “Let’s walk through your testing options together.” “I believe you.” “Anything else you want to talk about today?”
Those are small phrases that carry big weight. They’re what turns a sterile clinic into a space of care. They’re what makes a Black woman like me feel like more than a risk profile or a chart number.
Because I’m not just a patient — I’m a person. A woman who deserves information without shame, protection without judgment, and care without question.
We deserve that. Not just once. Not just if we ask nicely. We deserve it every single time we walk through the door .
